title: Corrections & Amplifications
text:
A Walmart Inc. spokeswoman said stores in most states have a five-per-day limit on baby formula at the request of the Food and Drug Administration. In some editions Wednesday, a Business News article about baby-formula supplies incorrectly attributed the statement to Target Corp., which declined to comment for the article.

United States Steel Corp. intends to add a machine for producing pig iron at its Gary, Ind., mill. A Business News article on Wednesday about pig-iron prices incorrectly said U.S. Steel intends to devote one of its Gary blast furnaces to producing pig iron.

Albertsons Cos.' Chief Financial Officer Sharon McCollam has acknowledged overhang from the company's convertible preferred shares on a relatively small stock float, and BMO Capital Markets' Kelly Bania estimated that if all of those shares were converted, the float would nearly double from today's 20%. In some editions Wednesday, a Heard on the Street column about Albertsons incorrectly attributed the term "dilution" to Ms. McCollam and Ms. Bania.

Readers can alert The Wall Street Journal to any errors in news articles by emailing wsjcontact@wsj.com or by calling 888-410-2667.

Corrections & Amplifications
